description: On January 23, 2020, the Coordination Office of Measures on Emerging Infectious Diseases, Cabinet Secretariat (Japan), established a website on "Countermeasures Against the Novel Coronavirus".
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In this context, it was agreed to “d) Take necessary measures for children who have temporarily returned from China, including supporting their acceptance and preventing bullying at schools.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In this context, it was agreed to “b) Call on consumers and businesses to remain calm and refrain from overstocking, to ensure there are enough masks and other goods necessary for the people.”

On March 12, the Hiroshima Prefecture issued a warning to warn against scams: "Counseling regarding fraudulent e-mails and phone calls using the "new coronavirus" is sent to the Consumer Affairs Counseling Service in the prefecture."
On March 27, Saga Prefecture Governor condemned "incidents where businesses refuse people's entries just because they're foreigners".

By making friends with the LINE official account "Okayama-Personal support for new corona countermeasures" and entering your status, we will inform you about the new coronavirus according to your status, as announced on April 2.

By joining the LINE official account "Okayama-Personal support for new corona countermeasures", the Okayama Prefecture (Japan) can inform its citizens about the new coronavirus according to their status, as announced on April 2.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) will “call for a calm response in order to prevent confusion including panic buying of food, medicine and daily necessities.”
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) “will work with the government in informing the residents that the emergency measures are different from "lockdown" (city blockade).”
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). In order to guarantee the (1) Provision and sharing of information, it was agreed to “[i]nform the public that the government will not take measures such as "lockdown" (city blockade), and call for a calm response from the people (self-restraint of travel across prefectures, such as nonessential visits to hometowns and travel, avoiding flooding of shops and panic buying).”

description: In Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) from April 8, "police warn people to be cautious" about "corona-linked fraud" and to "consult others when encountering such suspicious situations". For example, there had been cases of victims who "failed to receive surgical masks and other sanitation products they ordered online" and of "suspicious emails and phone calls offering corporate bonds" to develop corona cures.

On May 12, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) posted a warning against potential scams related to the coronavirus: "There have been some consultations such as suspicious e-mails and telephones masquerading as the payment procedure for special fixed benefit, which is suspected of being scammed by a new coronavirus infection."

On May 13, the Hiroshima Prefecture issued an announcement to its citizens that suspicious phone calls, emails and short messages (SMS), social networking services (SNS), websites, etc. regarding new coronavirus infectious diseases and special fixed benefit have been confirmed. Please be careful of unfamiliar phone calls, e-mails, and websites so that you will not fall victim to crimes caused by these new coronavirus infections.
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In relation to the new coronavirus infection, slanderous slander against infected persons, their families, persons involved in medical institutions, persons in specific countries, and unsubstantiated and discriminatory writings on SNS etc. are seen. Such acts are human rights violations and are not permissible. On June 18. the Okayama Prefecture is asking all citizens of the prefecture to act from the standpoint of the other person based on the correct information announced by the national government and local governments.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 18. the Okayama Prefecture is asking all citizens of the prefecture to act from the standpoint of the other person based on the correct information announced by the national government and local governments. Such acts are human rights violations and are not permissible."

description: In early August, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) initiated a campaign to create an advertisement that shows that infection risk can be eliminated by basic measures in buses, taxis, and trains, and we have begun posting them on the bodies of taxis, high-speed, chartered buses, etc.

description: On August 25, 2020, the draft “Ordinance on Cluster Measures for Preventing the Spread of New Coronavirus Infection in Tottori Prefecture” was approved after a revised decision at the extraordinary session in August 2 of the Tottori Prefectural Assembly (Japan). description: Japan, on Apr. 13 Akita government announces the temporary closure of prefectural schools and Akita technical college. "Due to the outbreak of this infection, we decided to temporarily close the prefectural schools and Nishi Senboku High School in Akita City, Oga City, Katagami City, and Nanaki Area from today until April 26." "Prefectural schools have resumed classes on April 6th, except in some areas, but we will stop these schools for the time being to prevent the spread of infection. In addition, Akita Technical College in Akita City will also be temporarily closed from today until April 26."

Schools subject to temporary closure: Matsue Kita High School, Matsue Minami High School, Matsue East High School, Matsue Technical High School, Matsue Commercial High School, Matsue Agriculture and Forestry High School, Shinji High School

description: On May 1, 2020, the Minister of Education, Science and Technology of Japan (MEXT) Hagiuda Koichi announced the release of "guidelines on how schools closed due to the coronavirus outbreak could resume classes in stages." "The guidelines propose staggered attendance by grade or class, with priority given to the first and final grades of elementary schools and seniors at junior high schools." The Ministry "also said that schools should divide children into groups by using unused classrooms and keep distances of one to 2 meters between seats. The notice proposed staggered class schedules by time and by day. It also said that physical education and other activities should not be conducted in congested environments."
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
According to the state of infections in the prefecture, and while paying the
utmost attention to infection prevention, the Shimane Prefectural Board of Education is planning for all prefectural schools—except those in Matsue—to have “Distributed School Attendance” for regular teaching from May 18th.  During this period, students that have concerns about the health of themselves or family members, or concerns about infection, are not required to attend; such students will not be marked as absent.

description: On April 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo declared that "the virus has been spreading in six prefectures — Hokkaido, Ibaraki, Ishikawa, Gifu, Aichi, and Kyoto — to the same extent as in the seven prefectures where the state of emergency originally applied. Those seven are Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Hyogo and Fukuoka." Accordingly, the "13 prefectures have now been designated as "special alert prefectures" where it is necessary to promote efforts to prevent the spread of infections."
Hokkaido Prefectural Government announces a state of emergency "to prevent the further spread of COVID-19" from April 17 to May 31.

On April 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe, "expanded [...] the state of emergency beyond seven prefectures to the entire nation in an attempt to prevent the new coronavirus from spreading further and straining the health care system."
On April 17, 2020, the town major of Taketomi (Ishigaki, Yaeyama Islands, Okinawa) Nishiomasu Kojun declared the island's own state of emergency in order to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus.

On May 4, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo announced that the Government of Japan "intend[s] to request the Expert Meeting to assess the [emergency] situation" on May 14. The Government of Japan will "ask the Expert Meeting to conduct detailed analyses on the trend of new cases in each area and the degree of pressure on medical treatment structures."

On May 4, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe, "extended a nationwide state of emergency to May 31, saying the new coronavirus infection rate had yet to drop enough to justify ending measures aimed at slowing the outbreak."
The original end of the prefectural state of emergency was May 6, and it has been extended to May 31.

On May 6, 2020, the Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi, in charge for Economic Revitalization, announced that "[l]ifting state of emergency to be reviewed on a weekly basis." "Having extended its nationwide state of emergency by a month, the government now says it will consider week by week whether to lift it earlier and offered May 21 as a new date, depending on infection rates."
Following the national government on May 14, the Shimane Prefectural Government has lifted the state of emergency and will relax restrictions.

On January 31, 2020, at the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that Japan "will deny entry of individuals who are infected by the virus in accordance with the Immigration Control and Refugee Recognition Act. Based on the fact that individuals have tested positive for the virus with or without symptoms, [the Government] must further improve the effectiveness of border controls."

description: At a press conference on June 23, 2020, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan MOTEGI Toshimitsu announced that "it has been decided to operate special flights from Japan to Viet Nam over the three-day period on June 25, 26, and 27 arranged by the Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Viet Nam. Through these flights, it is planned for about 440 Japanese residents and businesspeople to travel to Viet Nam. They will be the first flights from Japan to Viet Nam since the agreement to relax restrictions partially and gradually on mutual travel between our countries. For this travel, the people who go to Viet Nam will enter the country in accordance with Viet Nam’s designated process of measures to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus. Also, among the travelers, businesspeople who will return to Japan after a relatively short time are expected to enter Japan in accordance with the trial measures for entry based on the decision made last week on June 18 by the National Security Council (NSC) and the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters. Specifically, on the condition that they comply with additional infection control measures, it is expected that measures will apply to them that enable limited business activities during the 14-day waiting period, such as waiting at home."
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On January 8, Fukuoka Prefecture requested that residents who have symptoms such as coughing or fever after returning from Wuhan City should go to a medical institution.
On January 16, Fukuoka Prefecture requested that residents who have symptoms such as coughing or fever after returning from Wuhan should call a medical center.

On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting decided that "if it is confirmed that a person is infected at a medical institution, the National Institute of Infectious Diseases should  arrange proper inspection and retrace the close contacts of the infected person."

On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting decided to "implement national border control measures, such as checking the health status of people entering the country from areas with a high risk of infection, with tools such as thermographies at quarantine stations."

On January 28th, the Hokkaido Department of Health issued a statement regarding the health monitoring of travelers. After surveying 22 traveling participants, the Department confirmed that two displayed symptoms of COVID-19. All travelers who have tested positive are requested to implement anti-infection measures in the hospital, and all Hokkaido citizens are requested to monitor their health, particularly those who plan to travel or come into contact with travelers.

On January 28th, the Regional Health Division of Hokkaido asked citizens with suspected symptoms to "wear a mask and undergo a medical examination." Once having undergone examination, patients will be contacted with test results. Patients are asked to observe their health for 14 days, and in case of specified infections, are recommended to admit themselves to a hospital.

On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that "[t]aking into consideration the fact that individuals have tested positive for the virus despite exhibiting no symptoms, it is necessary for us to phase up our responses including quarantine measures. [...] We will introduce a measure, aimed at all people entering Japan with any history of travelling to Wuhan or related areas, that checks their contact information while in Japan and follows up on their health status, regardless of whether or not they have exhibited any symptoms."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed to “A) b) Encourage people to contact the Call Center for Japanese Returnees and Potential Contacts, which refer suspected patients to outpatient facilities from the viewpoint of accurately grasping the situations of outbreak and preventing the further spread, as seeking medical care without consulting due to the anxiety from potential infection may lead to increased risk of infection.”

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to “(2) understan[d] the situation of infection in Japan,” it was agreed to “B) Establish the surveillance system to grasp the epidemic situation in Japan, while switching to use of PCR test for the confirmation of diagnosis necessary to treat pneumonia patients who require hospitalization, in communities where the number of patients continues to increase."
"Fukuoka Prefecture is providing health consultations for COVID-19 related matters via telephone" from 25 February 2020
"Fukuoka Prefecture is providing health consultations for COVID-19 related matters via telephone" from 25 February 2020

Fukuoka Prefecture advises from February 25 that residents with "cold symptoms or high fever" (37.5 degrees Celsius or more) for more than four days and continual "excessive fatigue or difficulty with breathing" should phone a medical centre for consultation.

Fukuoka Prefecture advises from February 25 that residents with "cold symptoms or high fever" (37.5 degrees Celsius or more) for more than four days and/or continual "excessive fatigue or difficulty with breathing" should phone a medical centre for consultation.

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed that “B) a) The elderly and those with underlying diseases are encouraged to seek appropriate medical care at the early stage, given their vulnerability to the infection.”

Saga Prefecture set up a 24/7 phone line from March 1 "exclusively for foreign residents to help them speak to the consultation centers in 18 languages" regarding coronavirus symptoms. The provided languages are English, Chinese, Korean, Vietnamese, Malay, Nepalese, Tagalog, Bahasa Indonesian, Portuguese, French, Spanish, Russian, Italian, German, Thai, Burmese, Khmer and Mongolian.

Kagoshima Prefectural Coronavirus Infectious Disease Control Headquarters requests from March 27 for residents to call the Japanese Returnees and Potential Contacts advice line in the event of a long term fever, symptoms of tiredness, suffocating or difficulty in breathing.

On March 30, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) announced the promotion of health monitoring measures on its village ferries. Body temperature and health conditions of crew members will be checked every day. Before boarding the ferry, the temperature of passengers will be taken. These measures will be effective from April 1, 2020.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, “[t]ake every possible precaution to prevent workers from being a source of infection by thoroughly avoiding the place where "3Cs" overlap at the same time, by making sure for workers to wear masks, wash and disinfect hands, disinfect regularly shared facilities, maintain a certain distance each other when eating and drinking, keep their daily health tracks and stay home if their physical condition is not perfect.”

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, prefectural governments “will provide guidance to school operators on infectious disease countermeasures such as health management.”

On April 7, 2020, the Welfare Department of Tarama Island and Tarama Clinic asked residents to contact the clinic "if you have been out of Okinawa or outside the prefecture or if your relatives have been visiting you from Okinawa main island or from outside Okinawa prefecture after March 20." "Regarding homecoming high school children due to the prefectural extension of public high school closure, please measure the temperature twice daily and monitor cough, runny nose, sore throat." [loose translation from Japanese]
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Naha Airport in Okinawa Prefecture (Japan) has voluntary installed thermography devices to measure the body temperature of passing customers and has started to distribute leaflets with health recommendations to those exceeding the standard value on April 9, 2020. No access restrictions are being performed.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "7) Strengthening counter-cluster measures" it was decided that "i) Active epidemiological investigations will be organized to identify individuals who have been in close contact with infected persons, monitor their health conditions, request them to refrain from leaving home, and properly grasp the scale of the spread of infections for appropriate infection control."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: The Okayama Prefecture says to its citizens to contact a consultation center if any of your symptoms continue for four days or longer. If you feel that your symptoms are strong, please consult immediately, as the symptoms vary with the individual. This also applies to those who are taking antipyretics.) We ask that individuals with symptoms take leave from work or school and refrain from going out.

As of May 22, the Okayama Prefecture (Japan) is mandating its citizens to contact a consultation center if any of their symptoms continue for four days or longer. "If you feel that your symptoms are strong, please consult immediately, as the symptoms vary with the individual. This also applies to those who are taking antipyretics.) We ask that individuals with symptoms take leave from work or school and refrain from going out."

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In order to guarantee the (2) Surveillance and Information gathering, it was agreed to “[b]uild a framework for effective surveillance, such as surveys on antibody prevalence.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
Japan (Tokyo), on June 05, 2020, "in order to safely use the metropolitan facilities visited by many users, [the Tokyo Metropolitan Government] build a new 'Tokyo version of new corona watching service' from the viewpoint of preventing the spread of new coronavirus infection".
"This service is a mechanism that promptly notifies the user of infection information based on the visit history of the facility when a new coronavirus infectious disease cluster occurs in a metropolitan facility."
Targeted facilities include Metropolitan cultural facilities, sports facilities, gardens/zoos, libraries, etc. (will be expanded in the future).

On June 19, 2020, the Government of Japan has begun "offering a smartphone app that alerts users of close contact with people infected with the novel coronavirus. The Cocoa app is aimed at preventing the spread of the virus by urging users with infection risks to get tested as soon as possible. [...] When users who have installed the app on their smartphones are located within a meter of each other for 15 minutes or more, their devices will exchange information of the encounter via the Bluetooth wireless technology and record it for 14 days. When a user is confirmed to be infected with the coronavirus, the local public health center will issue a code that the user can enter on the app. A server will gather information on the individual's encounters with other users, and notify them via the app that they had been in close contact with the infected patient."

On June 19, the Saga prefecture (Japan) announced that it will be using the mew coronavirus contact confirmation application (COCOA), developed to contribute to extended prevention of new coronavirus infectious disease in Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 22, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) has "temporarily stop[ep] the app from issuing any alerts," as it "erroneously accepts reference numbers not issued by the Health, Labor and Welfare Ministry." "To prevent confusion, officials have halted the issuance of personal numbers. This means the app's contact-notification function will remain out of service. Officials say they plan to fix the flaw as soon as possible."

On June 23, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) has "temporarily stop[ep] the app from issuing any alerts," as it "erroneously accepts reference numbers not issued by the Health, Labor and Welfare Ministry." "To prevent confusion, officials have halted the issuance of personal numbers. This means the app's contact-notification function will remain out of service. Officials say they plan to fix the flaw as soon as possible."

Japan, on June 26, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government announced, it will implement the "'Store-type Tokyo version of New Corona Monitoring Service', an infection information notification service regarding cluster outbreaks of new-type coronavirus infectious diseases based on the history of visits to private stores by users", in cooperation with several Corona Tech partner companies (Event Resist Co., Ltd., Yahoo Japan Corporation, Ikkyu Co., Ltd.). The business will start on June 27, 2020.
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 3, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) has "resumed its coronavirus contact-tracing app service." "The ministry says users need to update their app to the latest version."
From July 15, Fukuoka Prefecture encourages residents to use COCOA, "a contract-tracing application developed to prevent the spread" of COVID-19.

On July 22, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) established a branch office of the Traveler’s Access Center Okinawa (TACO) at Miyako Airport. The office will provide health consultations for visitors. If fever is confirmed, it will be possible, with the consent of the patient, to transfer with a dedicated car from the airport to Miyako Hospital in order to conduct a PCR test.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On July 24, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) urges its citizens to visit the consultation center if they had visited the Koyama Chinese Cuisine in an effort to conduct contact tracing with novel coronavirus cases.
As announced on July 31, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) will utilize more digital technologies to more efficiently detect and track cases.

On August 3, the Tottori Municipal Public Health Center (Japan) announced the planned implementation of the examination for the faculty members of Tottori City Higashi Junior High School and all the school students in relation to the 15th case positive in the prefecture (12th case of the Tottori City Public Health Center).
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On August 5, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) launched a coronavirus countermeasure security system. 

"If a person who is positive for the new coronavirus is found among the participants of a large-scale event held in Tottori Prefecture, a service will be sent from the prefecture to alert the recipients to the email address registered at the venue."

On August 12, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that it "plans to ask elderly facilities to simulate a coronavirus outbreak by the end of August, as part of its resurgence response." "Staff at the facilities will also be asked to check stock levels of sanitary goods such as disinfectant and face masks and how they are checking the health of the staff. With the steps, the ministry aims to prevent an infection cluster among elderly people with a higher risk of developing serious conditions." "Facilities will have to report to the ministry by early September on whether they have taken the steps. Facilities required to carry out such simulations are special elderly nursing homes, nursing care facilities, homes for the elderly with care services and other establishments where many old people live together."

On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked schools to "continue to make every effort to prevent infections" and families to "cooperate in observing the health of their children."

As of August 14, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) will begin using its new "Hiroshima Corona News QR" service that uses QR codes to inform citizens that they may have contacted an infected person and supports them to have a PCR test to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infections.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 28, 2020, at the 42nd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government “implement[s] regular screening all at once for all those who work at medical institutions and care facilities for the elderly so as to prevent group infections among people at high risk of developing severe symptoms.”

On 29 January 2020, Osaka Prefecture, Japan, established a telephone consultation service for citizens of the prefecture. The consultation service is available everyday, including weekends and public holidays from 9:00AM to 6:00PM.

On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe clarified that, concerning the 210 Japanese nationals returned to Japan from Wuhan as of January 30, 2020, the Government "intend[s] to take all possible measures in monitoring their health, while continuing to make sure that all individuals who wish to return to Japan are able to do so [and] conduct thorough health checks regardless of symptoms, including virus screening, and make government facilities such as training centers fully available for accommodation for the duration of that process."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On January 31, 2020, at the Fourth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that "[e]ven for those individuals who have tested negative, [the Government is] thoroughly monitoring health condition of each and every person under appropriate controls, by stationing doctors at all accommodation facilities on a round-the-clock basis, [and] also providing push-mode support for daily living essentials, including face masks, sanitizers, thermometers, and other daily items, to those privately-owned accommodations and government facilities who have pledged their cooperation."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 5, 2020, at the Fifth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that the Government is "working on developing systems to enable private testing institutions to conduct screenings that the National Institute of Infectious Diseases and Public Health Institutes have been conducting."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 5 February 2020, Nara Prefecture established a Returnee/Contact Person Telephone Consultation Centre for those who suspect that they have been infected with the new COVID-19 virus.

On 5 February 2020, Nara Prefecture established a Returnee/Contact Person Telephone Consultation Centre for those who suspect that they have been infected with the new COVID-19 virus. 

From 25 February 2020, the opening hours of the Centre will be extended. On weekdays, the Centre will be open between 08:30 and 21:00. The weekend hours will remain the same as before, from 10:00 to 16:00.

"The Government of Japan decided to provide China with 4,800 safety goggles and 5,200 isolation suits, which are part of the equipment stockpiled by Asia-Europe Foundation (ASEF) and financed by Japan’s contribution, as in-kind contribution from the Government of Japan. This in-kind contribution was transported to Wuhan by the chartered flight which left Japan on Wednesday, February 6, and handed over to the Chinese side at Wuhan Tianhe International Airport on Thursday, February 7."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 6, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) instituted a new "telephone consultation service" for the new coronavirus. The new consultation desk will be reachable free of charge from 9am to 9pm at the number 0120-565653, starting from February 7, 2020.

Since February 10, 2020, "Yokohama [(Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan)] has set up a call center to handle inquiries about the coronavirus." "The move comes after it received more 1,100 phone calls directed to public health care centers around the city since Jan. 16. The call center is open from 9 a.m.-9 p.m., seven days a week, including holidays."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 13, 2020, at the Eight Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that the Government "will extend supports to secure over 1,800 beds among medical institutions across Japan that are capable of accommodating patients."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 16, 2020, at the Tenth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that "the Government will more closely collaborate with local governments and implement various measures, including [...] a 24-hour response, including Saturdays and Sundays, by the 536 consultation centers which were established in each and every prefecture."

description:
On February 17, the Tottori prefecture issued a statement, urging its citizens to contact a "Coronavirus Consultation Center" if they have any of the below symptoms:
(1) Cold symptoms and/or a fever above 37.5 degrees Celsius which lasts for 4 days or more (2 days or more for the elderly or those with preexisting health problems.)
(2) Heavy physical fatigue or trouble breathing
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: At the end of February 2020, Japan National Tourism Organization (JNTO) "published a webpage titled, "For Safe Travels in Japan: Guide for when you are feeling ill," which allows users to find medical professionals in their area that speak English, Chinese, and Korean, plus other languages (Polish, French, German) that are less available. It also includes a brief guide for how to use travel medical insurance and typical Japanese hospital procedures. The tourism site also launched the Bebot x JNTO chatbot, which gives users information on COVID-19, restrictions on travel from China, travel insurance, as well as the option to "speak to human.""
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 5 February 2020, Nara Prefecture established a Returnee/Contact Person Telephone Consultation Centre for those who suspect that they have been infected with the new COVID-19 virus. From 25 February 2020, the opening hours of the Centre will be extended. On weekdays, the Centre will be open between 08:30 and 21:00. The weekend hours will remain the same as before, from 10:00 to 16:00.

description:
On 5 February 2020, Nara Prefecture established a Returnee/Contact Person Telephone Consultation Centre for those who suspect that they have been infected with the new COVID-19 virus. From 25 February 2020, the opening hours of the Centre will be extended. On weekdays, the Centre will be open between 08:30 and 21:00. The weekend hours will remain the same as before, from 10:00 to 16:00.

From 1 May onwards the opening hours will be adjusted again. The new opening hours are: Monday to Saturday open 24 hours and closed on Sunday. The fax contact number will also be changed.

On February 26, 2020, Okinawa Prefecture "has established a help desk for COVID-19 as well as the countermeasures for virus infection." Okinawa Prefecture "has set up a round-the-clock hotline serviced by medical professionals who provide information on medical institutions that can handle foreign languages. The service is available in English, Mandarin, Cantonese, Korean, Portuguese, Spanish, Vietnamese and Thai."

According to the Ministry of Justice of Japan (MOJ), inmates of "seven prisons in Aomori, Kyoto, Osaka, Hyogo, Yamaguchi and Kochi prefecture" have been sewing "cloth face masks" since March 2020. "Having received orders from private-sector companies, these prisons now have the combined capacity to sew some 66,000 such masks a month. They also started preparations to make medical gowns that are in short supply as well."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: In Sendai, to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infectious diseases, BCG vaccination in March is, as a general rule, carried out only for children who are one year old by the beginning of April and have not been vaccinated. If the vaccination period can be delayed, please inoculate after April. For children who are currently eligible for vaccination, parents will be notified individually.

"Japanese Defense Minister Taro Kono issued on Saturday [(March 28, 2020)] an order to dispatch Self-Defense Forces troops as part of his country's efforts to strengthen quarantine steps amid the spread of the new coronavirus. From Saturday, the dispatched troops are engaged in the work to quarantine people arriving at Tokyo International Airport at Haneda and Narita International Airport in Chiba Prefecture, east of Tokyo. They are also supporting the transport of such people to designated facilities. The Defense Ministry dispatched SDF members on a voluntary basis based on a judgment that the current situation represents a case stipulated by the SDF law where the ministry should not wait for a dispatch request from a prefectural governor."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

On April 6, 2020, at the 26th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government will "urgently refurbish pre-fab facilities intended for police units, which were set up for the Tokyo Olympic and Paralympic Games to use as accommodation." description: On April 11, 2020, Japan has announced measures to "ease the shortages of medical supplies at medical sites". "45 million surgical masks [will be distributed] to medical institutions nationwide; a further 10 million to these institutions in the seven prefectures" affected by the declaration of a state of emergency. "Regarding medical gowns and face shields, [...] 1 million of each [will] be distributed to the seven prefectures, subject to the degree of scarcity. As for N95 and KN95 masks, [...] 70,000 masks within next week and 700,000 by the end of the month [will be delivered].

On April 14, 2020, Osaka Prefecture "began to treat mildly ill or asymptomatic patients of the novel coronavirus at a business hotel in the city of Osaka [...] in an effort to prevent the local medical system from collapsing amid the crisis. The prefectural government has set aside funds for 3,000 rooms for such people." Moreover, "13 hospitalized people moved to Super Hotel Osaka Natural Hot Springs. [...] Nurses will be at the hotel for full-time services to check patients' conditions every day and respond to any sudden changes in their conditions. At the hotel, 400 rooms are secured for coronavirus patients."

description: On April 22, 2020, the Government of Japan expressed its plan "to strictly limit foreign investment in makers of medical goods and drugs amid the novel coronavirus pandemic." "The government fears that if foreign capitals, particularly Chinese, buy up Japanese manufacturers of ventilators and other advanced medical apparatuses, it will become difficult to sufficiently check domestic production and exports of such products, whose stable supply is indispensable to national security."

description: On April 24, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "[m]ore day care and short-stay facilities for the elderly have shut as the government expanded the state of emergency over the coronavirus crisis nationwide April 16." Kagoshima Prefecture announced on 24 April that three accommodation facilities have been secured to treat patients with mild cases of COVID-19.

On April 24 2020 the Minister of Health Labour and Welfare of Japan MHLW approved the domestic production and sales of ventilators for severe patients by Japanese medical equipment manufacturer Nihon Kohden in Japanese <U+65E5><U+672C><U+5149><U+96FB><U+5DE5><U+696D><U+682A><U+5F0F><U+4F1A><U+793E> The company plans to start production soon at its factory in the city of Tomioka Gunma Prefecture Nihon Kohden plans to produce several hundred units a year and begin sales in July To increase domestic production the health ministry has decided to speed up the screening process for companies Nihon Kohden received approval in four days as opposed to the typical four months

When a person who is insured by Tottori City National Health Insurance (Japan) is infected with a new coronavirus infection or has a fever etc, the Tottori Prefecture will pay the allowance. Registration began on April 27.

At a news conference on April 28, 2020, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan MOTEGI Toshimitsu announced that "Japan will begin providing the anti-flu drug Avigan for free to 38 countries as early as this week for treating patients with the new coronavirus." The Minister added that "over 70 countries, including the 38, have made requests for Avigan to Japan, which has decided to offer a $1 million grant to the United Nations Office for Project Services to buy and distribute the drug, also known as favipiravir, to countries that want it."

description: At the beginning of May 2020, the Cabinet Office of Japan told Japanese local governments "to make preparations to prevent the spread of the coronavirus at evacuation centers if natural disasters occur, ahead of the rainy and typhoon seasons." The Cabinet Office prompted "the local governments to set up as many evacuation centers as possible in the event of disasters and consider in advance how to cope with infected evacuees."

On 5 February 2020, Nara Prefecture established a Returnee/Contact Person Telephone Consultation Centre for those who suspect that they have been infected with the new COVID-19 virus. From 25 February 2020, the opening hours of the Centre were extended (weekdays between 08:30 and 21:00, weekend hours from 10:00 to 16:00). 
   
From 1 May onwards the opening hours will be adjusted again. From Monday to Saturday, the Centre will be open for 24 hours and then the Centre will be closed on Sunday. The fax contact number will also be changed.

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "i) A hospital treatment system will be secured that focuses on providing medical care to those with severe symptoms" it was decided that “A system will be set up to coordinate the acceptance and transfer of patients. Medical institutions' information-gathering systems will be utilized so that the institutions can visualize information necessary for coordinating patient acceptance."

The ministry aims to start the service for Line users in early 2021 at the earliest after a system upgrade."

description: On May 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) “approved remdesivir as the first treatment for COVID-19 in Japan, three days after the Japanese subsidiary of U.S.-based Gilead Sciences Inc. submitted the application. The process was accelerated under a special exception clause for pharmaceuticals that are approved by another nation with comparable standards as Japan’s.” “The health ministry will initially manage the supply and distribute remdesivir to hospitals with patients with severe symptoms. The drug will be provided for free at first.”

On May 9, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government (Japan) has "released a stockpile of data on the number of coronavirus tests conducted and the infection rate dating back to late January. Disjointed data on testing, not just in Tokyo but throughout Japan, has been the subject of controversy and scrutiny for months. Researchers say it’s impossible to understand the true severity of the pandemic without this information."

On May 9, 2020, it was announced that a "group of researchers at the University of Tokyo has started clinical trials of [...] [n]afamostat mesylate, [...] marketed under the brand name Futhan. The tests are being conducted on 160 patients with pneumonia stemming from the coronavirus at the University of Tokyo Hospital and five other medical facilities in Japan. The patients are divided into two groups. One group is administered Futhan and anti-flu drug Avigan. The other is given only Avigan. University of Tokyo Professor Inoue Junichiro is involved in the trials."
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan)  submitted an additional supplementary budget of approximately 2.4 billion yen as the third step of emergency additional support for new coronavirus infectious diseases. This will increase the number of PCR tests to 440 cases and secure more empty beds for hospitalization.

This will increase the number of PCR tests to 440 cases and secure more empty beds for hospitalization.

On May 22, 2020, the Government of Japan "adopted an ordinance revision [...] to ban the resale of sanitizers and products that can be used as an alternative to disinfectants at prices higher than the acquisition costs." "The revised ordinance, which will come into force on Tuesday, will cover the resale of pharmaceutical and quasi-pharmaceutical products, such as sanitizers and alcohol-based hand soap products, and sanitizing products with an alcohol concentration of 60 pct or higher. Products without alcohol or not designed for disinfection will not be covered. Consumable alcohol of high concentrations will not be restricted either if it is resold for consumption."

If a person who is enrolled in the National Health Insurance System is infected with the new coronavirus (including cases where there is a symptom such as fever and infection is suspected), he/she will be able to pay the injury/illness allowance for the period during which he/she cannot receive labor for medical treatment, as announced by the Okayama prefecture on May 27. 
For more information, please contact your local municipal health insurance counter or the National Health Insurance Society.

description: On May 26, Fukuoka Prefecture allocated 1.7 billion yen to "funding for the development of medical environments" related to COVID-19.

On June 4, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo said that "Japan will provide about $300 million to a global organization dedicated to increasing access to vaccinations in developing countries. The financial support to Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, will be extended for five years from 2021 to make contributions to global public health efforts. [...] The Japanese government provided around $95 million to Gavi for the previous five-year period from 2016 to 2020. The upcoming donation of $300 million, including $100 million already pledged in April, is the largest amount Japan has provided to the nongovernmental body to date."

On June 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "opened a website where users pick the type of problem they are facing over the novel coronavirus to look for support measures that match their needs." "The website also has a mental health test function." "Smartphone users found to be stressed out can directly seek advice using the Line free messaging app."

description:
As published on July 8, the Okayama Prefecture (Japan) has suspended group examinations due to worries about the spread of the coronavirus, switching instead to individual medical checkups of infants and toddlers. Checkpoints will proceed until the end of July. 

"The shift is aimed at preparing health care workers and the wider medical system for an expected second wave of COVID-19 infections."

On June 15, 2020, the Minister of Finance of Japan (MOF) "added medical fields to the list of domestic industrial sectors subject to foreign investment restrictions to maintain domestic control over cutting-edge technologies including those related to dealing with the coronavirus pandemic." "The tighter controls on pharmaceutical products and advanced medical equipment under the foreign exchange and foreign trade law will take effect" on July 15, 2020. Already on April 22, 2020, the Government of Japan expressed its plan "to strictly limit foreign investment in makers of medical goods and drugs amid the novel coronavirus pandemic." "The government fears that if foreign capitals, particularly Chinese, buy up Japanese manufacturers of ventilators and other advanced medical apparatuses, it will become difficult to sufficiently check domestic production and exports of such products, whose stable supply is indispensable to national security."
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: It was announced on July 22 that Fukuoka Prefecture had "began accepting patients with no or mild symptoms at designated hotels again".

As announced on July 31, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) is implementing hospitalization measures and expanding its inspection measures to prepare for a second wave of the coronavirus. 

"We will work to increase the number of cooperating medical institutions such as clinics that collect samples.

Disseminate saliva collection that can reduce the risk and burden of specimen collection at cooperating medical institutions. To that end, we will work to establish a test system that can smoothly collect and transport samples and increase the number of samples.

Until the testing by saliva collection is available at the cooperating medical institutions, we will expand the induction of PCR tests for those returning to the home or contact of those who are considered to need testing among those who have undergone medical examination."

description: On August 16, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "the government is preparing to send hospital and public health nurses to Okinawa Prefecture." "Nurses will be sent from other prefectures as a further spread of infections is expected to strain the island prefecture’s health care system in terms of hospital beds and personnel." On August 16, 2020, Okinawa Governor Denny Tamaki "asked for such assistance at a meeting with state minister of health Gaku Hashimoto. The central government will work with the National Governors’ Association so that about 10 hospital nurses will be dispatched within a week. The number will be raised to about 50 eventually. [...] The health ministry will also consider sending to Okinawa medical workers who can handle extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, or ECMO, life support systems and taking COVID-19 patients to hospitals outside the prefecture."

description: On August 28, 2020, at the 42nd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government “intend[s] to fundamentally enhance the structures, including securing the capacity to conduct an average of 200,000 tests per day at regional medical institutions.”

On August 25, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced that it "will set up a toll-free telephone hotline at 0120-762029 on Sept. 1 to offer consultations to foreigners having trouble making a living due to the pandemic. The service will be available in 14 languages, including Japanese."

It is expected to secure inspection capacity of more than 10,000 people by the end of September.”

description: On September 23, 2020, the Government of Japan announced that it "plans to open a website in October to book polymerase chain reaction tests for novel coronavirus infections before overseas travel. The website, named "TeCOT," will allow those planning international trips to check the necessary conditions for travel, which differ by destination, and reserve PCR tests."
Fukuoka Prefecture announced that it would distribute 93,000 N95 masks to 291 hospitals in the prefecture after October 12 to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

In Tokyo, Japan on October 8, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government announced the opening of accommodation facilities for COVID-19 patients wishing to stay with their pets.  The facility opened on October 12, 2020.

On August 7, 2020, the Government of Japan "has reached a basic agreement with AstraZeneca PLC to receive a vaccine against the novel coronavirus from the British drug giant if it is successfully developed." "Under the agreement, Japan will receive 120 million doses of the vaccine starting early next year. Of the total, 30 million doses will be supplied by the end of March. AstraZeneca will produce the vaccine also in Japan, in cooperation with JCR Pharmaceuticals Co." "The company plans to start trials in Japan later this month."

On August 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that the Government of Japan "has reached a basic agreement with AstraZeneca PLC to receive a vaccine against the novel coronavirus from the British drug giant if it is successfully developed." "Under the agreement, Japan will receive 120 million doses of the vaccine starting early next year. Of the total, 30 million doses will be supplied by the end of March. AstraZeneca will produce the vaccine also in Japan, in cooperation with JCR Pharmaceuticals Co." "The company plans to start trials in Japan later this month."

On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe clarified that, concerning the 210 Japanese nationals returned to Japan from Wuhan as of January 30, 2020, the Government "intend[s] to take all possible measures in monitoring their health, while continuing to make sure that all individuals who wish to return to Japan are able to do so [and] conduct thorough health checks regardless of symptoms, including virus screening, and make government facilities such as training centers fully available for accommodation for the duration of that process."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As appropriate, follow hospitalization procedures in accordance with the Infectious Diseases Control Law.”<U+2028>

description: On April 20, 2020, the National Institute of Infectious Diseases of Japan (NIID) "has changed the definition of people who had close contact with patients of the COVID-19 disease, caused by the novel coronavirus. To continue “(2) Surveillance and information gathering efforts,” the MHLW will “Strengthen the testing system by utilizing local and private institutes; Introduce new testing technology promptly in the medical field; [and] Promote the utilization of private testing institutes.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). To continue “(2) Surveillance and information gathering efforts,” the MHLW will “Grasp the PCR testing system and make necessary coordination.” “Furthermore, the MHLW will examine and evaluate the division of functions between PCR tests and antigen tests and implement more tests including PCR not only for medical personnel but also for other close contacts.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). To continue "(2) Surveillance and information" gathering efforts, the MHLW will “identify suspected disease carrier and conduct tests that the doctor considers necessary."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: The government will start testing 10,000 people in Tokyo, Osaka and Miyagi prefectures for coronavirus antibodies next month as part of efforts to better understand how it spreads.

On May 24, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "has decided to fully cover the cost of coronavirus PCR tests for near-term pregnant women." "Specifically, the ministry will provide subsidies to local governments subject to some conditions, which include that they decide in advance where to accept pregnant women who test positive."

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In order to guarantee the (2) Surveillance and Information gathering, it was agreed to “[i]dentify suspected disease carrier and conduct tests that the doctor considers necessary.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 22, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Kato Katsunobu announced that the Government of Japan"will conduct testing for coronavirus antibodies in Tokyo and two other prefectures, starting early next month for about 10,000 people." "The test will cover Tokyo and Osaka Prefecture, where the number of coronavirus cases per 100,000 people is relatively large, and Miyagi Prefecture, which has fewer cases."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On May 15, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Kato Katsunobu announced that the Ministry "will conduct COVID-19 antibody testing for about 10,000 people as early as next month. The testing will cover several prefectures, including those with many coronavirus cases and those with a few cases. The ministry plans to find out whether people have antibodies against the new coronavirus and the amount of antibodies a person has."

On June 2, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "it has approved the use of saliva samples in polymerase chain reaction tests for the novel coronavirus. Saliva use is available within nine days after people start developing symptoms of COVID-19, the respiratory disease caused by the coronavirus. [...] The new method is less risky as saliva samples are enclosed in special containers by patients themselves," thus reducing the "infection risks to medical workers."

Due to a new confirmed case of COVID-19 on July 2 in Tottori City, the Shimane Prefecture (Japan) is conducting PCR tests on its citizens, as announced on July 14.  

"We are actively conducting PCR testing; if you are concerned about possible infection, please first contact the Shimane International Center’s “One Stop Center” Consultation hotline for foreign residents."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 15, 2020, the Okinawa Chubu Central Hospital (Okinawa, Japan) "started collecting specimens for antibody surveys to be carried out by the Okinawa Prefectural Government in partnership with the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST) for a survey of the state of coronavirus infection in Okinawa. [...] The same will be carried out at the Public Kumejima Hospital. Collection of antibodies will start at prefectural hospitals in the northern and southern parts of Okinawa Island, Miyako, and Yaeyama as soon as approval is received from the ethics review committee."

At the event "The ROSE" in Fukuyama City, Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan), held on July 10th (Friday), multiple people with the new type coronavirus infections occurred.

"In response, the Fukuyama City Public Health Center has called on bar users to undergo PCR testing."

On July 25, 2020, Okinawa Prefecture (Japan) "began PCR testing for Japanese citizens who work in the U.S. bases." "By July 24, Okinawa had contacted the over 800 people who work at Camp Hansen and MCAS Futenma through organization such as the Okinawa Defense Bureau (ODB) for testing." A testing site was established at "a community center in Okinawa City."

On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with the extension of its declaration of a state of emergency, agreed on measures to expand the medical care provisioning system and further prevent the spread of infection. In order to strengthen border measures, the TACO system at Naha Airport will be enhanced by opening up the possibility of antigen testing.

On August 28, 2020, at the 42nd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government “will make all possible efforts to secure screening capacity for over 10,000 people at Narita Airport, Haneda Airport and Kansai International Airport by next month, and further advance the preparation of the necessary screening structures at other airports as well.”
As announced on September 28, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) will be carrying out prenatal coronavirus tests to relieve the anxiety of pregnant women from Thursday, October 1st.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed to “B) c) Strengthen infection control measures and secure essential goods for controlling the infection in medical institutions.”

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(3) measures to control the infection,” it was agreed to “A) c) Take general infection prevention measures at public transportation facilities, roadside stations, and other facilities where a large number of people gather.“

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(3) measures to control the infection,” it was agreed to “A) b) Take general infection prevention measures in facilities such as facilities for the elderly.”

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed to “B) d) Take general infection control measures thoroughly to prevent the infection from spreading in the facilities for the elderly if there is a suspected case of the novel coronavirus infection, while ensuring the smooth transition to hospitalized medical care for those with the high risk.”

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee (3) Pandemic prevention, it was agreed to “[e]nsure thorough infection control measures in places including the followings”: “Medical institutions; Elderly facilities; School; Public transport; Workplace (actively promote tele-work and staggered commuting).”

description: On March 30, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) announced the promotion of hygienic measures on its village boats by crew members, such as wearing of masks, hand washing, disinfection of equipments and supplies, proper coughing etiquette, and air ventilation. Customers are expected to collaborate. These measures will be effective from April 1, 2020.

On March 30, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) announced the promotion of hygienic measures on its village ferries by crew members, such as wearing of masks, hand washing, disinfection of equipments and supplies, proper coughing etiquette, and air ventilation. Customers are expected to collaborate. These measures will be effective from April 1, 2020.
Fukuoka Prefecture requests residents to wash hands and practice coughing etiquette between April 7 and May 6.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, “[t]ake every possible precaution to prevent workers from being a source of infection by thoroughly avoiding the place where "3Cs" overlap at the same time, by making sure for workers to wear masks, wash and disinfect hands, disinfect regularly shared facilities, maintain a certain distance each other when eating and drinking, keep their daily health tracks and stay home if their physical condition is not perfect.”

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Japan, on Apr. 22 Tokyo government announce, that it will "implement an emergency support project (new coronavirus infectious disease emergency measures) for ensuring safety and security for taxi and bus operators."
"Measures to prevent splash infection by separating the driver's seat and rear seat in a taxi" and "infection-prevention equipment on sightseeing buses" will be installed.

On April 27, 2020, the Ministry of the Environment of Japan (MOEJ) announced that it will "provide subsidies to help restaurants introduce high-performance ventilation systems to reduce the risk of infection with the novel coronavirus." "The subsidies will be paid to cover half to two-thirds of costs to install such advanced ventilation systems, which each costs about 500,000 yen. The ministry expects that the aid will cover a total of some 3,000 ventilation systems at 800 to 1,000 locations across the nation."

On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked business operators to comply with the "Infection Spread Prevention Guidelines" and to make use of the "shisa sticker"-system (which certifies compliance to the prefectural recommendation), "in order to minimize the impact on economic activities while strengthening infection control measures."

On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked schools to "continue to make every effort to prevent infections" and families to "cooperate in observing the health of their children."

On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked managers, staff and visitors of social welfare facilities, hospitals, and other facilities where people with a high risk of serious illnesses reside, to carefully follow measures of infection prevention.

On April 26, 2020, the Governor of Okinawa Prefecture (Japan) Denny Tamaki asked tourists "to stay away this year.

"I am sorry to tell you this but Okinawa is under a state of emergency," Tamaki wrote. "There is no way we can provide the very best ‘omotenashi’ (hospitality)." Tamaki is hoping to change people's minds about flying across the country to Okinawa while Japan is under the national state of emergency to control the spread of the novel coronavirus."

description: On May 4, 2020, "a committee of experts formed by" the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) "called on visitors, particularly from the 13 prefectures designated as "special alert areas," to continue to avoid travel to Okinawa in order to prevent the disease from being carried into Okinawa. description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to promote "1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)" it was decided that "ii) All designated prefectures will request citizens to refrain as much as possible from moving to other prefectures for reasons such as non-urgent and unnecessary homecoming visits or trips."

description: As part of Ishikawa prefecture's measures of the state of emergency, Ishikawa prefecture requested citizens not to visit or travel to other prefectures on April 16. description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures” it was decided that “i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully.” Prefectures not subject to emergency measures can “Promote avoiding movements of people between prefectures with relatively higher risk. Avoid going to places with ‘3Cs’.”

Note: The "3Cs" refer to closed spaces with poor ventilation, crowded and close-contact settings.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description:
Since the Tottori prefecture has been declared as an emergency, the infection has not been confirmed for more than a month, and the medical system is not under pressure, there are three secret facilities. After thorough avoidance and disinfection, we will not open for the prefecture facilities, as announced on May 23.
 We apologize for those who wish to use the facilities outside the prefecture because we are required to refrain from unnecessary and urgent movement across prefectures

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(3) measures to control the infection,” it was agreed that, B) a) In communities where the number of patients continues to increase; [to] switch to broader calls for refraining from going out, while reducing the scale of active epidemiology surveys and health observations on close contacts [and to] continue and strengthen the responses to clusters of patients, depending on the situation in the community.”

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) “will at first request a self-restraint of going out while indicating the period and area as necessary. Examples of outing that are not covered by such request would include activities necessary for maintaining daily life such as visiting hospitals, purchasing food, medicine and daily necessities, going to work as necessary, exercising outdoors or taking a walk.”

On 04/08/2020 Kumamoto Prefecture moved its coronavirus alertness level from 3 to 4. As a consequence of this, prefectural authorities demanded strongly that citizens do not travel out of the prefecture, and avoid any non-urgent and non-essential outings.

description: On February 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe "attended the first Novel Coronavirus Expert Meeting at the Prime Minister’s Office" and called for contributions from "experts who are working on the front line in the respective fields, to give due consideration based on the medical and scientific perspectives, including the characteristics of the virus and other knowledge we have gathered so far", adding that the "Government will introduce further countermeasures in advance, following the advice based on the medical and scientific perspectives proposed by this expert meeting." The Expert Meeting was announced on February 14, 2020, at the Ninth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters: "in order to advance deliberations over our countermeasures based on expert knowledge even more than ever before, we will establish an expert meeting under this Headquarters, which consist of infectious disease specialists working on the frontline in their respective fields, and strengthen our responses."

description:
On 6 July 2020, the Nara Prefectural Board of Education established a "talent pool" or "human resources bank" to assemble people who can work in schools at the primary, middle and high school levels as temporary teachers or support staff. Whilst schools are currently closed, many are concerned that COVID-19 will delay children's learning and so, the Nara Prefectural Board of Education will organise supplementary classes once schools reopen and ask those who apply to lead these classes and those without current teaching qualifications will be asked to provide support. Those who successfully register in the human resources bank will be able to address teacher shortages within schools if teachers are infected by COVID-19. In addition to temporary teachers, this human resources bank aims to assemble 550 learning instructors to assist with after-school supplementary classes and 140 school support staff to help with class preparations.

This human resources bank was established separately to the National Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology's human resources bank.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 8 August 2020 the governors of Japans 47 prefectures conducted a video meeting and compiled a list of urgent proposals to the national government in response to COVID19 The proposals include A request to increase the amount of extraordinary grants for local governments to fund various measures against the coronavirus pandemic  A revision to the special law for combating the coronavirus so that authorities can impose penalties on business operators that fail to cooperate with businesssuspension requests by local governments To consider extending the Go To Travel campaign so that tourismrelated industries and local economies can sufficiently recover In particular the areas impacted by torrential rains in July 2020  To provide more PCR test support and resources To increase dissemination of information on COVID19 to foreign nationals living in Japan through embassies and other means  Strongly request measures to prevent the spread of COVID19 at US military bases  To take action to eliminate prejudice discriminatory behavior and false rumoursThe governors also advise that people reconsider making trips during the Bon summer holiday season around the middle of August amid concern that the movement of people will spread the virus further
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)

description: On August 25, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced that "it will allow foreigners who completed technical training courses to get jobs outside their area of specialization if they are unable to return to their countries due to the coronavirus pandemic. In early September, the agency will start accepting applications for up to one year of employment under the new program, which is intended to rescue former trainees having difficulty finding jobs in Japan at a time when many companies are scaling down their businesses and cutting job openings amid the health crisis. The agency expects applicants to find jobs in agriculture, food and beverage manufacturing and other sectors suffering severe personnel shortages."
