Fukuoka Prefecture announced on April 17 that "medical facilities who treat new coronavirus patients will receive ¥300,000 per patient".

Japan's Immigration Services Agency announced on April 17, 2020, that the "Japanese government will exceptionally allow foreigners employed in the country as technical trainees or specified skilled workers to get jobs outside their area of specialization if they become jobless due to the coronavirus crisis." "Applications for employment under the measure will be accepted from Monday," April 20, 2020. "The measure is also designed to encourage foreign workers to switch to industries facing severe labor shortages."
type_text: relaxation of visa restrictions (bureaucratic opportunities have been created for those who previously had restrictions)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 23, 2020, the chairman of the Japan Business Federation (Keidanren) Hiroaki Nakanishi prompted companies “to be flexible in their recruitment activities for students graduating in spring next year amid the coronavirus crisis. He called on firms, for example, to allow such students to start working later than usual if the virus pandemic leads to a delay in their graduation and makes it difficult for them to join the companies on scheduled dates.”
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Japan, on Apr. 23 Tokyo government announces "STAY HOME Week - STAY HOME, SAVE LIVES" campaign, which will last from Apr. 25 until May 6. "[I]n order to prevent the spread of infection, in order to reduce the chances of contact between people by 80%, we asked all residents of Tokyo and prefectures and businesses to refrain from going out and to leave the facility."
type_text: To reduce the chances of contact between people by 80% Tokyo government decided to launch a campaign to make people staying home. Entertainment will be provided by several TV channelds etc.

description: Japan government dispatch 2nd aircraft to repatriate Japanese residents from Wuhan (China), further the government "asked that passengers without obvious symptoms agree to be transported by a bus provided by the government for virus tests at the National Center for Global Health and Medicine in Tokyo's Shinjuku Ward"
type_text: Japanese governemnt dispatches aircraft to repatriate Japanese residents, passengers are being asked to undergo tests.

description: On 1 May 2020, Nara Prefecture established the "Coronavirus Infectious Diseases Control Fund" and called for donations from citizens to support medical professionals and frontline workers.

description: Fukuoka Prefecture has "opened a telephone consultation center to support local medical workers and their families" to relieve their mental burdens on May 8.
type_text: Mental health hotline to support local medical workers who may be experiencing stress due to increased workloads as well as harassment and abuse.

description: On May 10, 2020, the Japan Society for Oriental Medicine announced that it "is set to study whether and how ethical herbal medicines and antipyretics given to novel coronavirus patients for symptomatic treatment have led to worsening in their conditions. The organization asked medical institutions in the country to provide data, including details of the drugs prescribed to patients and suspected patients of the COVID-19 disease from the virus to contain their fevers or coughs, developments of their symptoms in the 14 days since the start of treatment and whether their symptoms worsened or not. The group hopes to collect data on about 1,000 cases and analyze the data using a statistical method."
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 12, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced that "[i]n light of the various circumstances associated with the impact of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) and from the perspective of preventing its spread, as a measure to reduce congestion at the immigration counters for residency applications, the immigration counters will be accepting applications to change the status of residence and applications to extend the period of stay from those foreign nationals (excluding foreign nationals with the status of residence of “Designated Activities (Departure Preparation Period”)) whose expiration date (see note) for their period of stay is due in March, April, May June or July for an extended period of three months from the expiration date of the period of stay of the relevant foreign national."
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). With regards to ‘9) Other common issues’, it was decided that ‘iv) A help desk for business operators will be established, logistics will be secured, and a robust lifeline system will be ensured, etc., in order to support the smooth operation of businesses.’
type_text: Rather than constituting a restriction on businesses, this policy involves the creation of a help desk and logistics/lifeline system to support businesses
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: As a measure for supporting those who are finding it difficult to pay the rent for their current housing due to income decrease resulting from business shutdown, etc., the Shimane prefecture will pay rent to their landlords through local municipalities, as posted on May 20.
type_text: As a measure for supporting those who are finding it difficult to pay the rent for their current housing due to income decrease resulting from business shutdown, etc., we pay rent to their landlords, through local municipalities.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: As posted on May 20, the Shimane prefecture (Japan) will pay rent to its citizens landlords through local municipalities, as a measure for supporting those who are finding it difficult to pay the rent for their current housing due to income decrease resulting from business shutdown, etc.
type_text: As a measure for supporting those who are finding it difficult to pay the rent for their current housing due to income decrease resulting from business shutdown, etc., we pay rent to their landlords, through local municipalities.

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). To continue “(2) Surveillance and information gathering efforts,” the MHLW will “Build a framework for effective surveillance, such as surveys on antibody prevalence.” The current system will also be improved to “appropriately grasp excess mortality in flu and pneumonia deaths.”
type_text: To better "grasp" and understand coronavirus, the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) is building a framework for effective surveillance, such as surveys on antibody prevalence,
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Concerning the “5) Handling of schools,” it has been decided that “ii) The Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) will provide guiding principles for nursery schools and after-school children's clubs, etc. on the downsizing of childcare and temporary closure of facilities.”
type_text: Guiding principles for nursery schools and after-school children's clubs - not quite school closures because the principles are recommendations and its usage will depend on each prefecture
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures” it was decided that “i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully.” Prefectures not subject to emergency measures [thus excluding Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa and Saitama] can “Promote measures to reduce contact between people, including teleworking, staggered work hours, and bicycle commuting”.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting called for "swift and accurate information to the citizens, and endeavour to ensure safety and security." Moreover, the Ministerial Meeting prompted to "pay sufficient attention when handling personal information of infected persons."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On January 24, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe asked "that the public strictly adhere to prevention measures against the common cold and behave calmly without overly reacting."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: „In Tokyo [Japan], a telephone consultation service (call center) has been set up since January 29 (Wednesday), in response to outbreaks of new coronavirus infectious diseases, to respond to consultations from residents of Tokyo.“

In Tokyo, Japan, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government set up a telephone consultation service via a chatbot on the app LINE and a call center beginning January 29, to respond to questions and concerns of Tokyo residents  in response to outbreaks of COVID-19.

On February 7th, 2020, Hokkaido Prefecture issued statements to all forms of publics transportation, requesting that proper hygiene and safety measures be taken. All transportation employees are encouraged to wear masks and take sanitization measures.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On February 17, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "advised people to consult dedicated coronavirus-related offices at public health centers or other relevant facilities if they run a fever of 37.5 degrees Celsius or over for at least four days. Also asked to do so were people feeling lethargic or breathing difficulties severer than such conditions for influenza." In addition, the "ministry advised elderly people, those suffering from chronic diseases such as diabetes, and heart and respiratory problems, people on dialysis, those using immunosuppressive or anticancer drugs, and pregnant women to use the consultation services if their suspected new coronavirus symptoms continue for around two days, because their conditions could rapidly deteriorate if they are infected with the COVID-19 virus."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to guarantee “(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions,” it was agreed to “d) Provide appropriate information and support to Japanese who are staying in countries where the infection is spreading.”
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: On February 25, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) set up a fax consultation counter affecting the new coronavirus infectious disease for those who have difficulty hearing over the phone, such as those with hearing impairments, aphasia, and those with voice disabilities.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to guarantee “(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions,” it was agreed to “a) Provide accurate and easy-to-understand information and call on the people to encourage calm responses;” “b) Urge companies to encourage employees and other personnel to take leave if they have fever or other flu-like symptoms, and promote teleworking and staggering commuting hours, in order to reduce the opportunities for contact with patients and infected persons;” “c) Request, based on the opinions of the experts meeting, communities and companies to re-examine the necessity of hosting public events from the viewpoint of infection control, taking into account the spread of infection, and the conditions of venue, while the nationwide voluntary restraint shall not be requested at this time;” “d) Provide appropriate information and support to Japanese who are staying in countries where the infection is spreading;” “e) Provide appropriate and prompt information to the public, foreign governments and foreign tourists, to prevent the spread of infection in Japan, and to prevent rumors.”
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to guarantee “(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions,” it was agreed to “a) Provide accurate and easy-to-understand information and call on the people to encourage calm responses,” such as “provide accurate information that includes clinical information and the situations of the outbreak.”

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. description: On March 26, 2020, "Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike said that a lockdown may become “the only option left” should other measures fail to prevent a substantial outbreak", thus "call[ing] on residents to stay indoors during the weekend" and "prompting major businesses to close".
Hokkaido Board of Education advises all children to mask up at schools when campuses reopen.

description:
On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee the “(1) Provision and sharing of information,” the following polices will be adopted:
“a) Provide accurate information and clear message for the public, promote awareness-raising to help change people’s behavior, and encourage calm response.
- Provide accurate and clear information
- Ensure implementation of basic countermeasures against infection
- Ensure that people do not go to workplace, attend school or leave home if they are sick
- Dissemination of guidelines for visits to medical institutions (call for prior telephone consultation)
- Prevent discrimination against infected persons, close contacts and medical personnel.”
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On March 31, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) released "a video featuring popular fashion models" "to raise awareness of COVID-19 prevention among young people."

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). description: From April 13, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "has started using an illustration of "amabie," a kind of yokai, or ghost, which is believed to have the power to ward off pestilence, to call on young people for cooperation in the fight against the novel coronavirus. An awareness flyer with the illustration of amabie urging people to "stop the spread of the virus" has been posted on the ministry's website."

The Ministry of Defense of Japan (MOD) "has released an educational manual on the new coronavirus on its Joint Staff website" on April 14, 2020. "The manual, titled "To protect the safety of the people from the new coronavirus" [...] contains 39 pages of information on COVID-19. It was compiled under the supervision of the Ground Staff Office. The information is based on the knowhow of Japan's Self-Defense Forces (SDF) against infectious diseases."

description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Section 3 addresses "Pandemic Prevention" and in order to promote “1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)” it was decided that “ii) All designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa] will inform residents using the "Ten tips" "New lifestyle practices (examples)," etc. presented by the Expert Meeting.”

Note: The documents referred to are  “10 Tips to reduce contact with people by 80%” created on April 22, 2020 and “Examples of New Lifestyle Practices” created on May 1, 2020. Both were produced after meetings of the Council of Experts, translated by the MHLW ad “Expert Meeting.”

description: On May 9, Fukuoka Prefecture shared "revised guidelines" in preparation for a "disaster combined with circumstances involving the spread of COVID-19" and have advised "cities and towns" to revise their manuals "in accordance with the new guidelines by the end of May". Guidelines call for the avoidance of "closed spaces, crowded places, and close-contact settings" as well as "the use of additional accommodation facilities".
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description:
On 17 June 2020, Nara Prefecture in the lead up to the annual monsoon season/ rainy season during which Japan is prone is disasters, shared on their website evacuation guidelines and procedures. Furthermore, these guidelines include recommendations on how to prevent the spread of covid-19 during evacuation and refuge. 

In addition to basic stockpiling, Nara Prefecture asks citizens to prepare: masks, a thermometer, plastic bags, disinfectant solution/ hand sanitiser, wet tissues and towels.

In evacuation shelters, they ask citizens to wear masks, practicing good hygiene such as hand washing and cooperate with others in the shelter. To support this, the Prefecture has attached guides on hand washing,  hand washing without water, cough etiquette and hygiene management of shelter toilets. 

This policy includes and supports material produced by the National Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description:
Install the new coronavirus contact confirmation app "COCOA" to protect yourself and your loved ones, as announced on June 23 by the Tottori prefecture in Japan. 
 The new coronavirus contact confirmation application "COCOA" of the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare is a smartphone application that allows you to receive notifications about the possibility of contact with a person infected with a new coronavirus infection.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
The Tottori Prefecture (Japan) announced on June 23 to its citizens to install the new coronavirus contact confirmation app "COCOA".
 "The new coronavirus contact confirmation application "COCOA" of the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare is a smartphone application that allows you to receive notifications about the possibility of contact with a person infected with a new coronavirus infection."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on the public not to panic after a record 224 new coronavirus cases were reported in Tokyo," declaring that the "current situation is not as tense as it was in April, when the government declared a state of emergency over the pandemic." Prime Minister Abe Shinzo "called on the public, especially young people, to take steps to avoid infection."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On July 22, 2020, the Government of Japan kicked off the "Go To Travel campaign", a discount travel campaign. The campaign will be financed with ¥1.35 trillion yen "to promote domestic travel by anyone to any destination [within Japan] they wished with an up to a 50 percent discount via deals and vouchers. [...] But after a spike in coronavirus cases in Tokyo, the government announced a sudden decision to exclude travel to and from the capital." "The government hopes to support the tourism industry, hurt by the coronavirus pandemic, while taking care not to spread the virus further. Travel and accommodation businesses are required to take full precautions."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On August 5, 2020, Okinawa Prefecture (Japan) opened two official LINE accounts ("Okinawa Prefecture Official LINE Account" and "Okinawa Prefecture - Corona Countermeasures Personal Support") in order to send institutional information concerning the prefecture and spread information about new coronavirus infectious disease.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: Kagoshima Prefecture set up a COVID-19 consultation call center on August 6 to respond to COVID-19 related enquiries from citizens and businesses. The line is available 24/7 and a fax option is also available. There is also 24/7 support available in English, Chinese, Korean, Spanish and Portuguese. Support in Vietnamese and Thai is available on weekdays from 10am to 6pm.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On August 19, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) established a hygiene counseling service for businesses that operate accommodation facilities, restaurants, etc., and are confused about measures to prevent infection, measures to take if an infected person occurs, and refrain from reducing sales.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On August 21, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) opened a consultation dial to receive appropriate advice and information from dedicated staff 24 hours a day, directly for various consultations regarding symptoms related to new-type coronavirus infectious diseases, infection prevention, inspection methods, etc.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Fukuoka Prefecture requested residents from August 22 to "refrain from using restaurants", that "do not comply" with COVID-19 guidelines. i.e. those that do not display the prefectural government's "Infection Prevention" sticker. Restaurants that are covered include those with "close contact", serve alcohol, karaoke places that serve alcohol as well as other restaurants that serve alcoholic beverages.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On February 1, 2020, at the Fourth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that from February 1, 2020, "it has become possible to implement measures as a Designated Infectious Disease, including hospitalization for the patients infected by the novel coronavirus."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On February 12, 2020, during the Seventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, the Government of Japan "has made a "high-level" political decision to flexibly interpret existing legislation", "open[ing] the way to forcibly quarantining those suspected of having the virus by broadly interpreting relevant legislation."

On February 12, 2020, during the Seventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, the Government of Japan "has made a "high-level" political decision to flexibly interpret existing legislation", "open[ing] the way to forcibly quarantining those suspected of having the virus by broadly interpreting relevant legislation."

description: On February 13, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "Japan will revise an ordinance to enable the isolation of those infected or suspected of being infected with the new coronavirus during quarantine". From February 14, 2020, authorities will be allowed "to conduct compulsory hospitalization of infected people with no symptoms. [...] Under the revised ordinance, authorities will be able to isolate infected people through hospitalization and make people suspected of being infected stay at designated facilities, during the quarantine procedures before they enter the country. As people with no symptoms will be subject to the compulsory hospitalization measure, the government will cover their medical costs."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On February 18, 2020, at the Eleventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe invited "the public [...] to refrain from going outside, taking leave from school or work, when experiencing symptoms of a cold, such as a fever. [...] Creating an environment that makes it easy for students and employees to take days off is crucial and I would like to ask cooperation in this regard. Making use of means like tele-working is another effective approach."
From February 19, Fukuoka Prefecture called for residents with a cold to take a break from school or work and rest at home.

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(5) border control measures,” it was agreed that, “from the viewpoint of securing medical resources in Japan, quarantine operations will be shifted, according to measures to prevent the spread of infection in Japan and systems for providing medical care.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed that “B) a) patients with mild flu-like symptoms should stay at home unless otherwise specified, and seek medical care after consulting the call center or a family doctor, if their conditions change.”

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(3) measures to control the infection,” it was agreed to “A) a) Take the following measures in accordance with the Infectious Diseases Control Law if a patient is identified by notification of a physician or other means: the active epidemiology survey to be conducted by the public health center; and close contacts to be monitored for their health conditions and requested to refrain from going out. The local government shall use active epidemiology surveys to identify a cluster based on individual patient outbreaks in cooperation with the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare and experts, and request the necessary measures including closure of the related facilities and voluntary restraint of events if there is a possibility that such a cluster exists.”

As of February 26, the Tottori prefecture is urging all persons entering Japan from any region where there is a high risk of new coronavirus pneumonia infection, notably China, to apply for quarantine if they are experiencing any symptoms of cough or fever.

description: Japan, on Mar. 19 Yamagata government requests all people coming from abroad  to the prefecture to self-quarantine for two weeks.
Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike requested on March 25, 2020 "that residents refrain from going outside [...] for nonessential reasons" on the weekend of March 28 and 29, 2020.

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). As for (4) Medicare, it was agreed to “[e]stablish a system for those with mild symptoms to be cared at home, in areas where there is a risk that an increase in patients of the Coronavirus may interfere with the provision of hospitalized medical care for other severely ill patients.”
Japan, on Mar. 28 Akita govenor requests people „who have returned to or come to the prefecture from areas where many infected people such as Tokyo“ for self-quarantine for about 2 weeks.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). As for (4) Medicare, it was agreed to “[p]erform tests at the discretion of the doctor and, if a patient is found, provide recommendations and necessary measures for admission to hospitals to provide appropriate medical care.”
Japan, on Mar. 30 Iwate government requests people who are coming to iwate from Tokyo, Kanagawa or Saitama prefectures  to refrain from going out for 2 weeks.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, “[i]solate a suspected case immediately and implement infection countermeasures under the guidance of public health centers, in case of suspecting a new case of COVID-19 infection from hospitalized patients or users.”

On February 23, 2020, the Ghibli Museum (Mitaka City, Tokyo Prefecture) announced its closure from February 25, 2020 until March 17, 2020, "in mutual agreement with the City of Mitaka" and "in accordance to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government's decision to cancel or postpone its major indoor events for the next three weeks in order to curb the spread of the Novel Coronavirus (Covid-19)."

In Tokyo, Japan on February 23, 2020, the Ghibli Museum, located in Mitaka City, Tokyo Metropolis, announced its closure from February 25, 2020 until March 17, 2020, "in mutual agreement with the City of Mitaka" and "in accordance to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government's decision to cancel or postpone its major indoor events for the next three weeks in order to curb the spread of the Novel Coronavirus (Covid-19)."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to guarantee “(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions”, it was agreed to “b) Urge companies to encourage employees and other personnel to take leave if they have fever or other flu-like symptoms, and promote teleworking and staggering commuting hours, in order to reduce the opportunities for contact with patients and infected persons.”

Japan's Japan Sports Agency and Agency for Cultural Affairs, part of the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (MEXT) "asked some large sports and cultural events to be cancelled or postponed voluntarily by their organizers".

In response to this request, some stadiums, museums and other sites of tourism may be temporarily closed."

description: On March 13, 2020, the Ghibli Museum (Mitaka City, Tokyo Prefecture) announced an extension of its closure, originally planned until March 17, 2020, stating that "[a]s a result of discussions with the City of Mitaka, it was decided to extend the closure of the Ghibli Museum considering the status of the coronavirus spread. Under the circumstances, we will move the annual May maintenance ahead of schedule and reopen the museum on Wednesday, April 29th, 2020."
On March 13, 2020, Tokyo Skytree (Tokyo, Tokyo Prefecture) announced that it "will remain closed further notice out of consideration for the health and safety of our guests and associates."

The Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI), "with the cooperation of internet auction platform operators, requests that masks and antiseptics not be put up for auction for an unspecified period" from March 14, 2020. Accordingly, "Yahoo! Japan annouced on March 4 that it will cease to display masks on its auction platform for an unspecified time from Saturday, March 14" and "Mobaoku announced on March 5 that it will cease to display masks and antiseptics on its auction platform for an unspecified time from Saturday, March 14."
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 25, the Saga prefecture (Japan) announced that restaurants must have enough ventilation, reduce crowds of people, manage the use of appliances such as tongs on the use infection risk of new model coronavirus.

description: Kagoshima Prefecture requested from March 27 for "all tourism related workers" to "wear face masks at all times and wash their hands at regular and relevant intervals".

On March 21, 2020, "Japan Transocean Air (JTA) announced their plan to suspend 60 flight routes from Naha, Fukuoka, Miyako, and Ishigaki from March 29 through April 5. This decision was made due to reduced demand from passengers amidst the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. The suspensions include 10 routes between Fukuoka and Naha, 26 routes between Naha and Miyako, and 24 routes between Naha and Ishigaki."
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
Oita Prefecture announced on April 1 that "workplaces that remain open for essential social and economic services" should: 
1. "Thoroughly carry out precautionary measures (e.g. handwashing, good cough etiquette) in an out of the office and during commute" 
2. "Proactively incorporate telecommuting, staggered work hours and commute on bicycle"
3.  If staff show "fever or symptoms of cold", "refrain from working (or make alternative work arrangements such as telecommuting) and remain at home"
4. "Employ alternative work arrangements such as video conferences to cut back travel on business trips"

From April 2, 2020, Japan Post "has announced that it will temporarily stop accepting international mail destined for 153 countries. For 126 of those countries, the suspension is limited to EMS and air mail", whereas any type of delivery is suspended for the remaining 27. Moreover, "[i]tems which have already been accepted and cannot be dispatched to their destinations will be returned from the delivery offices to the senders in order."
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 1, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo invited airlines to "reduce the number of arriving air flight passengers from overseas" during the 25th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, by "[r]equesting airlines concerned to curb the number of arrival passengers to Japan by such measures as reducing the number of passenger arrival flights in order to ensure the appropriate implementation of quarantine measures." The measures should be implemented by April 3, 2020 0:00 JST "until the end of April, for the time being."
Makishi Public Market in Naha City, Okinawa, Japan, "has closed for two weeks [on April 4, 2020 at 5:30 p.m.,] after a worker was confirmed to be infected with the new coronavirus" on the same day.

On April 6, 2020 "the Minami-Daito Novel Coronavirus Task Force (led by Mayor Kensho Nakada) held its third meeting at the village hall. With infections spreading domestically and internationally, the Task Force requested that tourists as well as business travelers on non-essential, non-urgent business refrain from visiting the island. These requests were made to the Village Tourism Association and the Village Commerce and Industry Association respectively. Hotels and other lodgings are moving toward not accepting reservations through the end of April."

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, “[t]emporarily cease reception of visits except for emergency in order to prevent infection from visiting persons.”

The island of Zamami (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) has stopped taking new reservations to the village campsite from April 7, 2020, "to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus infection". "Those with no reservation will not be able to use the campsite."

On April 6, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) has stopped taking new reservations for Ama campsite starting from April 7, 2020, "to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus infection". "Those with no reservation will not be able to use the campsite."
Fukuoka Prefecture requested that between April 7 and May 6 that workers should "reduce contact" with people by working from home (telework), staggering work hours, and commuting by bike.
Fukuoka Prefecture requested that between April 7 and May 6 that workers should "reduce contact" with people by working from home (telework), staggering work hours, and commuting by bike.
Okinawa Churaumi Aquarium (Okinawa, Japan) and adjoined facilities close temporarily from April 7, 2020.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, “[c]onsider measures such as suspending or restricting temporary use of facilities such as day-care, limiting outings and overnight stays of inpatients and users, in areas where infection is prevalent.”

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) “should strongly promote teleworking. Even in case of going to work, efforts to reduce contact with people, such as staggered work hours and bicycle commuting will be promoted even more strongly than ever."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, businesses “that perform operations essential for ensuring the stability of people's lives and the national economy (exemplified in the attachment), are required to continue their operation, depending on the characteristics of the business, while fully taking measures to prevent the spread of infection.”

Okinawa Shimojishima Airport Terminal (Miyako Islands, Japan) will be temporarily closed from April 10, 2020 until May 6, 2020 due to the suspension of all its three flight routes that followed the declaration of emergency issued on April 7, 2020.

From April 10, 2020, Japan Post announced that the "temporary suspension of acceptance of international mail items, mainly EMS and parcel-post/letter-post items by air and SAL, started on April 2 will be extended for the time being from April 10." "In connection with this measure, the destinations subject to partial or entire suspension will be 160 countries/territories in total."

From April 16th to May 6th, Reiwa, the "Emergency Declaration" was issued to all prefectures, and we are strongly calling for the residents of the prefecture to refrain from going out unnecessarily and urgently. There is concern about an increase in the inflow of people from neighboring prefectures, which are expanding rapidly, to entertainment and amusement facilities.

 For this reason, the Yamaguchi prefecture decided to request all the related businesses to take leave as described below, based on Article 24, Paragraph 9 of the Act on Special Measures against Countermeasures against New Influenza, etc., as announced on April 20.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

On 21 April 2020, following the 5th Nara Prefectural Coronavirus Infectious Diseases Control Headquarters Meeting, a number of restrictions were implemented to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The Prefecture asks that from April 23rd to May 6th, certain facilities suspend their activities in accordance with Article 24, Paragraph 9 of the Special Measures Law. These include: recreation facilities, exercise and amusement facilities, theaters, private cram schools, driving schools, meeting/ exhibition facilities, commercial facilities other than stores that sell daily-necessities (essential goods).

On 21 April 2020, following the 5th Nara Prefectural Coronavirus Infectious Diseases Control Headquarters Meeting, a number of restrictions were implemented to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Although some facilities were asked to suspend their activities between 23 April and 6 May (which encompasses Golden Week), some are asked to remain open. Facilities that are requested to continue operating include: medical facilities, facilities for daily necessities (encompassing wholesale markets, grocery stores, essential goods sections in department stores, hardware stores, supermarkets, convenience stores), accomodation facilities, transportation, factories, financial institutions (banks, stock exchanges, insurance companies), media organisations, funeral homes, public baths, pawnshops, veterinarians, beauty salons, laundromats and garbage disposal related facilities.

However, these facilities/ services are asked to implement appropriate infection control measures or encourage remote work where possible. 

Restaurants and other hospitality businesses (including taverns) are also allowed to open, but with infection control measures and are asked to shorten opening hours and terminate the sale of alcoholic beverages at 7pm.

On April 23, 2020, the Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy
of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi, in charge for Economic Revitalization, "issued guidelines on what kind of steps governors can take to get business owners that continue to ignore government requests to suspend their operations." "The guidelines say governors are authorized to issue stronger "requests" or "instructions" to those who refuse to comply with initial requests without legitimate reasons.
The names and addresses of the businesses given such stronger warnings will be disclosed online or by other means."

On April 24, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Osaka, Japan, "revealed the names of six pachinko pinball parlors that have not followed its request to shut down in the fight against the novel coronavirus. It is the first time that the names of uncooperative businesses have been made public under Article 45 of the special coronavirus response law."
Supermarkets are requested to enforce special infection prevention measures
Hokkaido Prefecture requested that supermarkets enforce special "infection prevention measures" from April 24 to May 6.
Oita Prefecture "requests that recreational facilities (mahjong parlours, pachinko parlours, game arcades etc)" close from April 24 to May 6.

From April 2, 2020, Japan Post announced that the "temporary suspension of acceptance of international mail items, mainly EMS and parcel-post/letter- post items by air and SAL, started on April 2, will be extended for the time being from April 24." "Items which have already been accepted and cannot be dispatched to their destinations will be returned from the delivery offices to the senders in order. In addition, because of the global reduction of flights, considerable delivery delays are expected for outbound mail items to other countries/territories."

On April 20, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) announced the suspension of the High-Speed Queen Zamami ferry service from April 25, 2020 until May 6, 2020, along with time schedule changes for Ferry Zamami. In addition, during the same period, the inter-island Mitsushima route (between Zamami Island and Aka Island) will operate as scheduled, but the route to Aharen (which connects Zamami Island to Tokashiki Island) will be suspended.

To the citizens of the Yamaguchi prefecture, in order to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infectious diseases, refrain from going out, except for those who need to visit the hospital, purchase food, medicines and daily necessities, and keep outdoor activities such as exercise and walking. 


 On the other hand, it has been pointed out that it is necessary to prevent infections in places such as supermarkets, shopping malls, and parks that are used by many people. Please take note of the following and cooperate with us in preventing the spread of infections.


* Keep the number of people small and avoid crowds, and keep the distance between people appropriately.
* Observe the request to prevent infection at the place of use.

description: On April 28, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Kanagawa, Japan "named six pachinko parlors that had refused to follow the government's request for closure and remained open for business."

On May 1, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Kanagawa, Japan "ordered pachinko parlors that have remained open in defiance of the state of emergency over the COVID-19 pandemic to shut down." "In the afternoon, prefectural officials visited Amaterasu, the last remaining parlor, and directly issued the order, which is also non-punitive."

On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to implement "3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later) it was decided that "iii) Business operators and related organizations will take voluntary measures to prevent  infection that take into account both sustainable actions for the future and recommendations from the Expert Meeting."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to regulate "4) Going to workplaces" it was noted that, "ii) Based on the expectation that all designated prefectures will need sustainable measures in future, Measures to reduce contact with people, including teleworking, working in rotations, staggered work hours, and bicycle commuting, will continue."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to implement "3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later) it was decided that "i) Prefectures under Specific Cautions will issue requests to follow restrictions on the use of facilities that may cause infections to spread. If such requests are not met and no justifiable reason is given, prefectures will issue further requests and instructions based on the Act, and they shall publicize the fact. Additionally, considering the impact of the extended measures on society, the economy, and the lives and health of the citizens, the Governors of each prefecture may make appropriate decisions on opening facilities such as museums, art galleries, libraries and outdoor parks."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to regulate "4) Going to workplaces" it was decided that "i) Particularly in Prefectures under Specific Cautions, working in rotations at workplaces that require employees to come to work and teleworking will be strongly encouraged to reduce contact, including aiming for a "70 percent reduction in employees coming to work."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to implement "3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later) it was decided that "ii) In designated prefectures that are not included in the Prefectures under Specific Cautions, decisions will be made based on the local situation from the viewpoint of preventing the spread of infections and maintaining socio-economic activities."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). description: As a part of measures for Ishikawa prefecture's state of emergency, Ishikawa prefecture requested the suspension of business to specific sectors designated by special laws for preventing the virus. As the original prefectural state of emergency extended from May 6 to May 31, the request for the suspension of business also extended at the level of the same amount of days for state of emergency.

On May 1, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) announced that the operation of Ferry Zamami will be suspended every Tuesday but that the High-Speed Queen Zamami ferry service will be restored every Tuesday. Schedules have been re-arranged to enable day trips to Okinawa Main Island. Moreover, the route to Aharen (which connects Zamami Island to Tokashiki Island) will be suspended. These measures will be effective from May 11, 2020.

description: On May 14, 2020, the Japan Business Federation (Keidanren, <U+7D4C><U+56E3><U+9023>) released guidelines "for protecting workers from COVID-19 are expected to be referred to when companies resume business activities while taking precautionary measures, following the government's lifting of the coronavirus state of emergency for most of the country's 47 prefectures. The guidelines are intended for long-term use at least until treatment for the disease is established and a vaccine is developed." Moreover, it "called on member companies to introduce a four-day workweek system to reduce coronavirus infection risks" and suggested "further promotion of remote working, staggered commuting and social-distancing measures in workplaces." Keidanren asked companies to "take measures, keeping in mind that steps taken at workplaces will lead to the prevention of a further spread of the virus across the entire society."
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “4) Going to workplaces” it was decided that “ii) Based on the expectation that all designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Saitama and Kanagawa] will need sustainable measures in future, businesses engaged in work essential for ensuring the stability of people's lives and the national economy (examples given in the attachment) as well as businesses supporting such work, must continue operating, depending on the characteristics of the businesses, while taking comprehensive measures to prevent the spread of infections, including measures to avoid the 3Cs.

From the attachment: Businesses engaged in essential work include those: Maintaining Medical System; Continuing to protect those in need; Securing stable lives of the people; Maintaining the stability of the society; and Others (those who will have difficulty stopping the production line; operators who produce essentials).
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “4) Going to workplaces” it was decided that “ii) Based on the expectation that all designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Saitama and Kanagawa] will need sustainable measures in future, workplaces will be encouraged to put thorough measures in place to prevent infections and avoid the 3Cs.”

Note: The "3Cs" refer to closed spaces with poor ventilation, crowded and close-contact settings.

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures” it was decided that “i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully.” Prefectures not subject to emergency measures [thus excluding Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa and Saitama] can “Promote measures to reduce contact between people, including teleworking, staggered work hours, and bicycle commuting”.

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked business operators to actively introduce telework, implement the 3Cs at the workplace, and minimize the number of meetings and gatherings, or organise remote meetings instead. In the event of a mass infection, businesses are asked to immediately identify the source of the outbreak and request temporary leave or implement shortened working hours in the affected area.

description: Since the declaration of state of emergency on April 7, 2020, the offices of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) have decreased "the number of people who commute to work by utilizing teleworking" and implemented "measures for double shifts in various divisions". Large-scale trainings for new personnel and large meetings are being avoided. Within its diplomatic missions abroad, MOFA has been promoting infection control measures "such as hand-washing and cough etiquette, utilizing teleworking and staggered work hours, and preventing suspension of functions by dividing personnel into teams and coming to work". In addition, "various business trips and the like have of course been reduced to the absolute minimum amount necessary", and officials "either work at home or commute to work" according to a "split-team structure". Over-the-counter services have been affected by "shortened counter hours", the introduction of "appointment systems", and extensions to "document processing times".
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) “should strongly promote teleworking. Even in case of going to work, efforts to reduce contact with people, such as staggered work hours and bicycle commuting will be promoted even more strongly than ever.”
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On April 7 and April 9, 2020, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued declarations concerning “MOFA’s structure and efforts in the case of the declaration of a state of emergency,” which was realised on  Planned and adopted measures include “teleworking”, “the introduction of a split-team structure” where “personnel [is divided] into two teams that either work at home or commute to work, including for diplomatic missions,” and decrease of “the total number of hours spent working in person at MOFA.” Moreover, “diplomatic missions have been taking infection control measures in the same way as MOFA including thoroughly promoting practices such as handwashing and cough etiquette, utilizing teleworking and staggered work hours, and preventing suspension of functions by dividing personnel into teams and coming to work. Also, various business trips and the like have of course been reduced to the absolute minimum amount necessary.”
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description:
On 8 May 2020, Nara Prefecture announced the temporary closure of "Nara Mahoroba-kan"- a souvenir store and tourism centre. The "Nara Mahoroba-kan" will be closed until May 31st. 

From 1 June "Nara Mahorobakan" will reopen but with reduced opening hours. Between June 1st to 12th, the business hours will be 11:00 to 19:00 (Usually from 10:30 to 19:30).
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to implement ‘3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later) it was decided that ‘i) Prefectures under Specific Cautions (Tokyo, Osaka, Hokkaido, Ibaraki, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Ishikawa, Gifu, Aichi, Kyoto, Hyogo, Fukuoka) will issue requests to follow restrictions on the use of facilities that may cause infections to spread. If such requests are not met and no justifiable reason is given, prefectures will issue further requests and instructions based on the Act, and they shall publicize the fact. Additionally, considering the impact of the extended measures on society, the economy, and the lives and health of the citizens, the Governors of each prefecture may make appropriate decisions on opening facilities such as museums, art galleries, libraries and outdoor parks.’
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On February 17, 2020, the Imperial Household Agency announced the cancellation of the "public birthday event for Emperor Naruhito at the Imperial Palace", which was originally scheduled for February 23, 2020. description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to guarantee “(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions,” it was agreed to “c) Request, based on the opinions of the experts meeting, communities and companies to re-examine the necessity of hosting public events from the viewpoint of infection control, taking into account the spread of infection, and the conditions of venue, while the nationwide voluntary restraint shall not be requested at this time.”

description: On April 2, 2020, "the Okinawa Medical Association (Tetsuyoshi Asato, committee chair) announced [...] that, with the opening of the tomb sweeping festival (shimi) season taking place this weekend, they are asking people [...] to keep gatherings small." description: Japan, on Apr. 02 Yamagata government requests to refrain from gatherings over the weekend : „Over the weekend, please do not gather in large groups and reduce the number of people you have contact with.“
Fukuoka Prefecture requests that residents "avoid poorly ventilated spaces, crowded spaces, and close contact with people" from April 2.

Oita Prefecture requested from April 4 for "all residents" to avoid "events that involve crowds unless it is essential". Furthermore, "younger individuals, who often do not exhibit symptoms, should exercise extra caution".

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) “will make request to restrict the holding of events that may lead to the spread of infection. When a request is not met with no justifiable reason, instructions will be issued and these requests and instructions will be made public.”

description: "Japan's Imperial Household Agency said [on April 13, 2020] that it has decided to cancel this year's Imperial spring garden party, scheduled for May 27, because of the spread of the novel coronavirus. The event was due to be hosted by Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako. The agency holds a garden party hosted by the country's Emperor and Empress in spring and autumn every year, at the Akasaka Imperial estate in the Motoakasaka district in Tokyo's Minato Ward, with some 2,000 guests."
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 14, Fukui Prefecture Government requests citizens to refrain from going out until May 6.

Due to COVID-19, Kumamoto Prefecture "scaled down" a ceremony to mark the fourth anniversary of two earthquakes. The number of attendees was reduced from 350 to 26 and "spaces between seats were widened to minimize person-to-person contact and help prevent infection".

description: On April 26, 2020, the All Japan High School Athletic Federation "decided to cancel this year's Interscholastic Athletic Meet," (otherwise known as Inter-High School Sports Festival) scheduled to be held from August 10, 2020 to August 24, 2020 "in venues in 21 prefectures." "This year's high school meet for 30 sports was expected to bring together 30,000 people."

description: "Fukuoka Prefecture announced parking-lot closures" at four parks (Ohori, Nishi, Najima Sports, Kasuga Parks) "during the Golden Week holidays" from April 29 to May 6.

On May 1, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced its "plan to utilize provisional release actively for foreigners detained in custody facilities before deportation due to illegal stays and other reasons." "The agency decided to utilize provisional release actively for detainees with no infection symptoms, except for those who have committed serious crimes, as custody facilities often have enclosed and congested environments involving close contact, with high infection risks. In addition, the guidelines include isolating new detainees for around two weeks and limiting visits to detainees to consular officers and lawyers."

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to regulate ‘6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures’ it was decided that ‘i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. One such sustainable measure was given as ‘Have organizers of nationwide, large-scale events (larger than a certain scale) demonstrate caution by cancelling or postponing them.’
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 14, 2020, the Okinawa Zento Eisa Matsuri executive committee announced "that they would be canceling the 65th Okinawa Zento Eisa Matsuri (hosted by the executive committee: Okinawa City, Ryukyu Shimpo Co. Ltd., Okinawa Television, the Okinawa Tourism and Industry Promotion Association, and the Okinawa City Youth Council), originally scheduled for September 11-13, due to concerns over the coronavirus." "The festival takes place at Okinawa City Stadium" in Okinawa City, Okinawa Prefecture, Japan, featuring "Eisa performances by groups from Okinawa City and elsewhere."
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description: On May 15, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Yamanashi (Japan) announced that "it would shut the route on its side to the top of the Japan's tallest mountain," Mount Fuji (Yoshida trail). "Usually, the Fujinomiya, Subashiri and Gotenba trails on the Shizuoka side and the Yoshida trail on the Yamanashi side open between July and September."
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description: On March 25, 2020, "the Okinawa Peace Movement Center (Chairman Hiroji Yamashiro) held an action committee meeting, at which it was decided that the 43rd 5/15 Peace March would be cancelled." "The rally, which was to be held on the final day of the event, was also cancelled. These actions were taken as measures to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus." "The 5/15 Peace March is held every year to draw attention to the importance of peace. The event spans 3 days, falling around May 15 when Okinawa was returned to mainland Japan."
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 18, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Shizuoka (Japan) announced that "it will close all three trails on Mount Fuji on the central Japan prefecture's side this summer, following the spread of the novel coronavirus."
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description: On May 20, 2020, "the Japan High School Baseball Federation and The Asahi Shimbun, a sponsor of the tournament, decided on the cancellation" of the summer National High School Baseball Championship, which was scheduled to start on August 10, 2020, "because of the novel coronavirus pandemic. At the same time, the prefectural tournaments to determine the 49 competing teams in the summer championship were also scrapped."
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). The MHLW implements “2) Restrictions on holding events” and states that “All designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa] will make requests not to hold events where clusters could emerge or have gatherings under 3Cs circumstances, especially in cases of nation-wide or large events and gatherings.”
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures” it was decided that “i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully.” Prefectures not subject to emergency measures [thus excluding Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa and Saitama] can “Have organizers of nationwide, large-scale events (larger than a certain scale) demonstrate caution by cancelling or postponing them.”
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Section 3 addresses "Pandemic Prevention" and in order to promote “1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)” it was decided that “ii) All designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa] will discourage citizens from visiting eateries with hospitality services in downtown areas where clusters have emerged.”

description: Until May 31st, for the types of facilities that have experienced cluster outbreaks, Kyoto Prefecture asked people to cooperate in the restriction of their usage.

In order to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus in Sendai City, it was decided to cancel or postpone events that gather a large number of people indoors, events that provide meals, etc. In response to the change in the handling policy, we will gradually relax the event holding restrictions.
However, in principle, we will continue to suspend or postpone large-scale events that involve the movement of people across the country and wide-area events and events for which the risk of infection cannot be fully addressed.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description:
This year’s memorial events for the Great East Japan Earthquake have been canceled one after another due to the spread of the COVID-19.
Even in Iwate, the only prefecture in the country that has so far had no cases of infection, most events around the Golden Week holidays in May were canceled. Organizers are now worried that the pandemic may have a lasting impact on holding disaster-related events next year, when it observes the 10th anniversary of the deadly March 11 quake and tsunami, as operations of nonprofit organizations supporting victims are having trouble continuing their activities.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

Regarding the holding of large-scale events nationwide, we ask the organizer to take careful measures to cancel or postpone it if the risk assessment cannot be completed.

Japan, on Mar. 23 Iwate government requests residents to self restrain: "I would like to reiterate to the residents of the prefecture that avoiding the three conditions of infection, which are sealing, crowding, and close contact".

In Japan, Tokyo's governor said "Tokyo’s 14 million people should avoid visits to bars and restaurants, and put karaoke sessions on hold". Furthermore, residents have been asked to "refrain from going out in the evenings, and to refrain from all unnecessary outings at the weekend” This is effective until 12 April.

In Tokyo, Japan on March 25, 2020, Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike asked Tokyo residents to "avoid visits to bars and restaurants, and put karaoke sessions on hold".  Furthermore, residents have been asked to "refrain from going out in the evenings, and to refrain from all unnecessary outings at the weekend.” This recommendation is effective until April 12, 2020.
Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike requested on March 25, 2020 "that residents refrain from going outside [...] for nonessential reasons" on the weekend of March 28 and 29, 2020.

In Tokyo, Japan on March 26, 2020, Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike and the governors of neighboring Chiba, Saitama, Chiba, and Kanagawa prefectures held a joint teleconference, "urging their people to avoid leaving home for nonessential purposes, to prevent an explosive surge in COVID-19 infections."  The governors stressed avoiding crowds, poorly ventilated areas, and events in order to avoid a wide-spread lockdown.
Japan, on Mar. 27 Fukushima government asks residents to wear masks "[i]n the case that you have to go outside for essential reasons".

Hokkaido Board of Education advises from March 27 that as schools "open for the new semester", for "all parents and guardians to ensure

description: On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee (3) Pandemic prevention, it was agreed to “[p]resent appropriate measures to prevent clusters and reduce contacts, based on the local situations” and to “[c]all for cooperation in self-restraint in avoiding gatherings in closed spaces, crowded places, or close-contact settings. Pay particular attention to metropolitan areas.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: Japan, on Mar. 30 Iwate prefecture asks (especially young people) to refrain from participating in events and to work via telework if possible: „We call for the careful action of young people who find it difficult to detect infections, refrain from events, and cooperate with the implementation of telework.“

Japan, on Mar. 31 Fukushima government requests residents to refrain from going out and avoid crowded places when showing symptoms. Furthermore “Three Cs”- “Closed spaces with poor ventilation”, “Crowded places with many people nearby”, and “Close-contact settings such as close-range conversations”should be avoided.
Japan, govenor of Wakayama asks residents for self restrain, especially to consider when to leave home.
Japan, on Apr. 1  Yamagata government requests young people to refrain from going out in the evenings, i.e. to visit drinking establshments and restaurants.

From April 2, 2020, the Ministry of Defense of Japan (MOD) "has started introducing a rotating work-shift system to ensure that its operations can continue without disruptions in the event someone within its structure becomes infected with the coronavirus." "The notification instructs all departments [...] to divide their staff members into several teams. The teams will be put to work in different times of the day or told to work at home every other day."
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Japan "adopted a policy of having asymptomatic or mildly ill patients of the COVID-19 coronavirus disease stay at home, in hotels or certain other places, in areas where infections are rapidly spreading."

description: Japan, on Apr. 03 Iwate government requests people to refrain from going out on weekends as wells as weekdays nights for the next two weeks: "„I would like you to be cautious about your activities, such as refraining from going out for "unnecessary urgency" on weekdays during the night and on weekends for the next two weeks.“

With infections spreading domestically and internationally, [...] [t]he Task Force asks residents to prevent the spread of the disease by wearing masks, washing their hands, and avoiding the 3 C’s: closed spaces, crowded places, and close-contact settings."

description: On April 6, 2020 "the Minami-Daito Novel Coronavirus Task Force (led by Mayor Kensho Nakada) held its third meeting at the village hall.
